ai.summary: Clunie Path is a challenging 22.7 km hike in the UK, featuring varied terrain, substantial elevation changes, and remote sections. It suits experienced hikers with good fitness and navigation skills, and it rewards perseverance with long-distance scenery. Expect a full-day trek with potentially exposed sections and sections where footing may be uneven.
ai.terrain_summary: The route combines rough tracks, grassy moorland, rocky slabs, and boggy or marshy patches. Footing is uneven and can be slippery after rain. Some sections are exposed to wind with open views, and navigation aids (map and compass) are advisable as signage may be sparse in remote parts.
ai.safety_notes: This is a hard hike requiring fitness, navigation, and planning. Plan for a full-day or longer; check the weather forecast and daylight hours. Wear sturdy, waterproof footwear and dress in layers; carry a waterproof layer. Bring a map and compass (or a GPS device) and know how to use them. Take enough food and water for the day, and inform someone of your planned route and expected return. Be prepared for changing conditions, boggy ground, and potentially remote sections with limited mobile reception.
recommended_gear: Backpack with enough capacity for food, water, and extra layers
Water or hydration system (2–3 litres recommended)
Map and compass (or GPS device) and knowledge of navigation
Fully charged mobile phone (with offline maps as a backup)
Headlamp or flashlight with spare batteries
First aid kit and personal medications
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (April–October) in the UK is ideal due to longer daylight and generally drier conditions. Winter hiking can be hazardous due to storms, ice, and boggy ground; if attempting in winter, it requires advanced preparation and caution.
